raw_text:
New York rockers top talent poll
 
 New York electro-rock group The Bravery have come top of the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll to find the music scene's most promising new act.
 
 The Bravery, who have been compared to The Cure and New Order, were the most heavily-tipped act in the survey of 110 impartial critics and broadcasters. Rock band Keane won Sound of 2004 while US rapper 50 Cent topped Sound of 2003. Other new artists in this year's list include London indie group Bloc Party at second and UK rapper Kano third. The Bravery played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported bands including The Libertines, Interpol and Echo and the Bunnymen.
 
 They were the subject of a record company bidding war in 2004 and their debut single, Unconditional, caused a huge buzz when it was released in the UK in November. Singer Sam Endicott said he felt "great" about coming top of the Sound of 2005 list. "Anyone that says they don't want a zillion screaming fans is a jackass, a liar," he said. One of the experts to tip The Bravery was The Times' music critic Paul Connolly, who said they were "spiky but in love with pop". Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, said the band had "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound". "The Bravery are proof alone that New York City is still home to hot new talent," he said. Nigel Harding, head of music at London rock radio station Xfm, said every track from their live set "sounded like a potential single".
 
 Unconditional reached the summit of the station's listeners' chart within a fortnight of its first play, which Mr Harding described as "an unheard of achievement for a debut single".
 
 Q magazine reviews editor Ted Kessler said they were "pretty-boy New York clothes horses" with "an unusually nimble ear for concise, yearning pop in the mould of Duran Duran or The Strokes". Other pundits to take part in the survey included BBC Radio 1 DJ Trevor Nelson, NME editor Conor McNicholas, Top of the Pops presenter Fearne Cotton, Glastonbury organiser Emily Eavis and BBC Radio 2 music editor Colin Martin. Elsewhere on the top 10, second-placed rock band Bloc Party began their rise after supporting Franz Ferdinand and UK garage MC Kano, in third, is signed to The Streets' record label. US rapper The Game is hip-hop great Dr Dre's latest protege while Leeds group Kaiser Chiefs came fifth with a promise to lead a Britpop revival. In last year's survey, Keane were followed by Franz Ferdinand, Razorlight and Joss Stone in the top five - all of whom were virtually unknown outside the music industry at that point.
 
 Boy band McFly were sixth while Scissor Sisters, who had the UK's best-selling album of 2004, were seventh. In the survey, the pundits were asked for tips for three acts they thought were capable of reaching the top in their chosen genre, either in terms of sales or critical acclaim. The artists could be from any country and any musical genre, but must not have had a UK top 20 single, been a contestant on a TV talent show or already be famous for doing something else, such as a soap actor. Those tips were then counted and compiled to make the top 10.
llama3.2:1b: New York rockers The Bravery have topped the BBC News Sound of 2005 poll with their debut single Unconditional, beating out other new acts such as Keane, Bloc Party, Kano, and Kaiser Chiefs.
llama3.2:3b: The Bravery, an electro-rock group from New York, have come top of the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll. They were compared to The Cure and New Order, and praised for their debut single Unconditional, which caused a huge buzz in the UK. Experts tipped them as "spiky but in love with pop" and said they had "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound". They played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported bands including The Libertines and Interpol.
gemma2:2b: The Bravery topped the BBC's Sound of 2005 poll, predicting its future success in music. The group was heavily tipped by critics and broadcasters and received significant buzz for their debut single "Unconditional." Other promising new acts on the list included Bloc Party, Kano, and Kaiser Chiefs, all experiencing considerable critical acclaim.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Bravery are New York electro-rock stars who topped a BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll this year, becoming one of the most promising new acts in the music scene. The group, with lead singer Sam Endicott, played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported bands like The Libertines, Interpol, and Echo and the Bunnymen. Despite facing competition from established artists such as Keane and 50 Cent, they maintained strong popularity among critics. The group also had success with Unconditional, their debut single that reached #1 in the UK's listeners' chart within a week of its release.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The New York rock band The Bravery topped the BBC Sound of 2005 poll, receiving votes from 110 critics including Paul Connolly at The Times, Chris Hawkins on BBC Radio 6 Music, Nigel Harding at Xfm, and Ted Kessler for Q magazine. They were tipped as "spiky but in love with pop" by music experts, supported major acts such as Interpol and Echo and the Bunnymen, and gained a record label deal. Their debut single reached the top of BBC Radio 6 Music's chart within a fortnight.
qwen2.5:3b: New York's The Bravery topped BBC News' Sound of 2005 poll for most promising new act. They were compared to bands like The Cure and New Order. They won Sound of 2004, with US rapper 50 Cent topping in 2003. Other artists include London indie group Bloc Party at second and UK rapper Kano third. The Bravery played their first gig in 2003 and have supported bands like The Libertines, Interpol, and Echo and the Bunnymen. Their debut single caused a buzz when it was released in the UK in November. They were tipped by critics like Paul Connolly of The Times ("spiky but in love with pop") and Chris Hawkins from BBC 6 Music's chart show ("great guitars"). Their single Unconditional reached the top of their radio station's listeners' chart within two weeks. Critics also mentioned Bloc Party, Kano, and The Streets' record label as other notable acts.

The Bravery were compared to The Cure and New Order, two other bands that had been mentioned as part of the survey. They were also compared to Rock band Keane who had come second in the same poll. Other new artists in this year's list include London indie band Bloc Party at second place and UK rapper 50 Cent who came third. The Bravery played their first gig in 2003 and have since supported bands including The Libertines, Interpol and Echo and the Bunnymen.
The Bravery were praised by one of the experts to take part in the survey, Chris Hawkins, who said they were "pretty-boy New York clothes horses" with "an unusually nimble ear for concise, yearning pop in the mould of Duran Duran or The Strokes". Other pundits to take part in the survey included BBC Radio 1 DJ Trevor Nelson, NME editor Conor McNicholas, Top of the Pops presenter Fearne Cotton, Glastonbury organiser Emily Eavis and BBC Radio 2 music editor Colin Martin. Elsewhere on the top 10, second-placed rock band Bloc Party began their rise after supporting Franz Ferdinand and Kaiser Chiefs in last year's survey. In last year's poll, the pundits were asked for tips for three acts they thought were capable of reaching the top in their chosen genre, either in terms of sales or critical acclaim. The artists could be from any country and any musical genre, but must not have had a UK top 20 single, been a contestant on a TV talent show or already be famous for doing something else, such as a soap actor. Those tips were then counted and compiled to make the top 10.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about The Bravery's performance in the Sound of 2005 poll. First, I'll read through it carefully to understand all the key points.

The article starts by mentioning that The Bravery came first on the BBC Sound of 2005 list and was tipped by some 110 critics. It compares them to The Cure and New Order. Then it talks about their previous gig in 2003, where they supported bands like The Libertines, Interpol, and Echo and the Bunnymen.

Next, the article mentions that they were involved in a bidding war with rock labels in 2004, which led to their debut single, Unconditional, being released. Sam Endicott was praised for his feelings of excitement about joining that list. A music critic, Paul Connolly, noted them as "spiky but in love with pop." Chris Hawkins from BBC 6 Music said they had great guitars and a masterful electro-clash sound.

The article also highlights the single's popularity within a week after its release and mentions other bands like Bloc Party who were part of the list. It notes that The Bravery have been very successful, especially in New York since their emergence.

There are other reviews by various pundits: Ted Kessler on their looks and sounds, Fearne Cotton about the band's live performance, and mentions of other notable artists like Dr Dre from The Game. The article lists several bands at the top of the list, including Q Magazine, Scissor Sisters, and others.

Finally, it says that despite being famous for rock music in New York, they are still cutting-edge talent. It wraps up by saying that their success shows how strong a city can be with young talent.

Now, I need to extract the main points:

1. The Bravery made it to Sound of 2005 first.
2. They were tipped by several experts.
3. Supported bands like The Libertines and others in 2003.
4. Did well in a bidding war for a single.
5. Their debut single, Unconditional, went viral within two weeks.
6. Critic opinions: they're "spiky but in love with pop."
7. Live performance at BBC's chart show was great.
8. They've had success beyond New York; other artists like Franz Ferdinand and Joss Stone were also part of the list.

I should keep only these key ideas, avoiding any extra details that aren't essential for summarizing.
</think>

The Bravery achieved first place on the BBC Sound of 2005 poll, being tipped by various experts. They supported bands such as The Libertines and were involved in a music label bidding war. Their debut single, Unconditional, reached the top of the chart quickly after its release. Critical opinions highlighted their versatility and creativity.

The band's debut single Unconditional also reaches the summit of the station's listener's chart within a fortnight of its first play, earning an unheared of achievement for a debut single. Other notable acts included London indie group Bloc Party in second place and UK garage MC Kano in third, with US rappers The Game and LeeDS group Kaiser Chiefs completing the top 5. Scottish boy band McFly were sixth, while American sci-fi rockers SciSSor Sisters came seventh. In its survey, punctuation critics were asked for their predictions for three acts they thought would achieve UK top 20 success, but could not be known to have a UK top 20 single or contestant on a TV talent show. The artists could come from any country and any musical genre, and must not have had a UK top 20 single, been a contestant on a TV talent show or already be famous for doing something else, such as a soap actor.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Bravery are a new rock band from New York who have just topped a BBC News website poll, which also included bands like The Cure and New Order. The band's single "Unconditional" is currently number one on UK radio charts, and their debut album has generated significant excitement among fans and critics alike. As mentioned in the text, this is just the second year in a row that The Bravery have made it to the top spot of the Sound of 2005 poll.

Ted Kessler of Q magazine described them as "pretty-boy New York clothes horses" with an ear for concise pop that reminded him of Duran Duran or The Strokes. Nigel Harding of BBC 6 Music said every track from their live set sounded like a potential single. Bloc Party, Kaiser Chiefs, and Scissor Sisters made it into the top 10 while McFly, The Game, Kaiser Chiefs, Kaiser Chiefs, Kaiser Chiefs, Kaiser Chiefs, Kaiser Chiefs, and Kaiser Chiefs were ranked sixth to tenth.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
The Bravery, an electro-rock band from New York, have been named the top act in the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll by a panel of 110 impartial critics and broadcasters. They were heavily favored due to comparisons with The Cure and New Order, and their debut single, "Unconditional," gained significant attention upon its UK release in November 2004. Other notable artists in the top 10 include Bloc Party (second), Kano (third), Keane (Sound of 2004), Fifty Cent (Sound of 2003), and a diverse group comprising rappers The Game, Dr Dre's protege; UK garage MC Kano; Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs; and boy band McFly. Additionally, Scissor Sisters, known for their successful 2004 album, placed seventh.

Experts tipped the Bravery as promising acts due to their skillful guitar work, mastery of electro-clash sound, and potential to attract a large fanbase. The panel included influential figures like Chris Hawkins from BBC 6 Music and Ted Kessler from Q magazine, who praised the band's pop sensibilities similar to Duran Duran or The Strokes. In last year's poll, Keane, Franz Ferdinand, Razorlight, and Joss Stone made up the top five, with most being relatively unknown outside the music industry at that time.
reference: New York electro-rock group The Bravery have come top of the BBC News website's Sound of 2005 poll to find the music scene's most promising new act.Singer Sam Endicott said he felt "great" about coming top of the Sound of 2005 list."The Bravery are proof alone that New York City is still home to hot new talent," he said.Chris Hawkins, host of BBC 6 Music's chart show, said the band had "great guitars and a mastery of the electro-clash sound".Elsewhere on the top 10, second-placed rock band Bloc Party began their rise after supporting Franz Ferdinand and UK garage MC Kano, in third, is signed to The Streets' record label.One of the experts to tip The Bravery was The Times' music critic Paul Connolly, who said they were "spiky but in love with pop".Other new artists in this year's list include London indie group Bloc Party at second and UK rapper Kano third.Rock band Keane won Sound of 2004 while US rapper 50 Cent topped Sound of 2003.The Bravery, who have been compared to The Cure and New Order, were the most heavily-tipped act in the survey of 110 impartial critics and broadcasters.
